questions.prompt: For matrix multiplication $AB$ to be defined, what must be true?
options: Number of columns in $A$ equals number of rows in $B$
Number of rows in $A$ equals number of columns in $B$
$A$ and $B$ must have the same dimensions
questions.explanation: For $AB$ to be defined, the number of columns in $A$ must equal the number of rows in $B$.

questions.prompt: Matrix multiplication is commutative: $AB = BA$ for all matrices $A$ and $B$.
questions.explanation: False. Matrix multiplication is NOT commutative in general. Even when both $AB$ and $BA$ are defined, they are usually not equal.

questions.prompt: If $A$ is a $3 \times 4$ matrix and $B$ is a $4 \times 2$ matrix, what size is $AB$?
questions.explanation: When multiplying an $m \times n$ matrix by an $n \times p$ matrix, the result is $m \times p$. So $3 \times 4$ times $4 \times 2$ gives $3 \times 2$.

questions.prompt: The transpose of matrix $A$, denoted $A^T$, is formed by:
options: Taking the reciprocal of each entry
questions.explanation: The transpose $A^T$ is formed by swapping rows and columns: the $(i,j)$ entry of $A$ becomes the $(j,i)$ entry of $A^T$.

questions.prompt: A matrix $A$ is invertible if there exists a matrix $B$ such that $AB = BA = $ ____.
questions.explanation: A matrix is invertible if there exists $B$ (called $A^{-1}$) such that $AB = BA = I$, the identity matrix.
The transpose of the inverse equals the inverse of the transpose: $(A^{-1})^T = (A^T)^{-1}$.

questions.prompt: An elementary matrix is obtained by:
options: Taking the transpose of a matrix
Performing one elementary row operation on the identity matrix
Multiplying the identity matrix by a scalar
questions.explanation: An elementary matrix is obtained by performing a single elementary row operation on an identity matrix.
True. Every elementary matrix is invertible, and its inverse is also an elementary matrix corresponding to the reverse row operation.

questions.prompt: A diagonal matrix has all nonzero entries:
questions.explanation: A diagonal matrix has all its nonzero entries on the main diagonal (where row index equals column index).

questions.prompt: If $A^T = A$, then matrix $A$ is called ____.
questions.explanation: A matrix is symmetric if it equals its own transpose: $A^T = A$.

questions.prompt: If $A$ and $B$ are invertible matrices of the same size, then $(AB)^{-1}$ equals:
questions.explanation: The inverse of a product is the product of inverses in reverse order: $(AB)^{-1} = B^{-1}A^{-1}$.

questions.prompt: The LU factorization of a matrix $A$ expresses $A$ as:
options: A sum of lower and upper triangular matrices
The transpose of a triangular matrix
A product of lower and upper triangular matrices
questions.explanation: LU factorization expresses $A = LU$ where $L$ is lower triangular and $U$ is upper triangular.

questions.prompt: If $A$ is a square matrix and $AB = I$, then $BA = I$ automatically.
questions.explanation: True. For square matrices, a one-sided inverse is automatically a two-sided inverse. If $AB = I$, then $BA = I$ as well.
A matrix is orthogonal if its transpose equals its inverse: $A^TA = AA^T = I$.

questions.prompt: The trace of a square matrix is the sum of its ____ entries.
questions.explanation: The trace is the sum of the diagonal entries: $\text{tr}(A) = \sum_{i=1}^n a_{ii}$.
